newsitem.title: FRANCE: Pernod extends gains after tax change.
newsitem.headline: Pernod extends gains after tax change.

text.p: Shares in French drinks group Pernod Ricard extended their gains on Wednesday after the government scaled back proposed tax hikes for spirits from 1997.
The share was up 2.15 percent at 280.50 francs at 1000 GMT, while the bourse's CAC-40 index was ahead just 0.3 percent.

Social Affairs Minister Jacques Barrot, under fire from spirit producers already reeling from falling demand, agreed to cut proposed tax hikes on spirits in the 1997 budget to 4.97 percent from 17.1 percent.
Pernod's stock rose 2.08 percent on Tuesday on reports that a parliamentary group was challenging the tax rise.
"Strong alcohol will be taxed less than planned," said Bruno Bourg-Broc, head of the cultural and social commission of the National Assembly, after hammering out a compromise with Barrot.

But the deal contained bad news for beer producers, who were originally due to escape higher taxes. Bourg-Broc said beers would be taxed nine centimes (0.17 cents) per 1/3 litre bottle. "Wines will escape taxation," he told reporters.
Pernod had been hit hardest among France's drinks group by the proposed spirits tax increase because the company is more dependent on the domestic market than its listed rivals.
